Executive Summary - Rothermel Conditioning Plant  

Devon Gas Services, L.P., owner and operator of the Rothermel Conditioning Plant, has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes.  Devon's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, facility trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release. 
Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

Inlet Separation and Cooling

Gas enters the plant at 925 psig and enters an inlet separator.  No free liquids are expected here as the gas is dry (less than 7 lb/MMCF water content) and above its hydrocarbon dew point.  Any unexpected liquids caught may be dumped directly to the stabilizer and mixed with plant product or dumped to atmospheric storage.  After separation the gas is cooled in a gas to gas exchanger and then chilled to -28 F in a chiller (heat exchanger) which utilizes a mixed refrigerant (Composition: approximately 60% R-143a, 35% R-125, and 5% R-134a).  The gas leaving the chiller contains condensed hydrocarbons; these are separated in the cold separator and fed to a product stabilizer with the gas from the cold separator (residue gas) returned to the gas to gas exchanger to cool the inlet gas.  

Product Stabilization and Storage

The product stabilizer utilizes an electric heater to boil the light hydrocarbons (methane and lighter) out of the product.  These are recycled to the inlet of the rich gas side of the gas to gas exchanger through a compressor.  The product from the bottom of the stabilizer is cooled in a heat exchanger to about 120 F and stored in pressurized product tanks.  The stabilizer will be operated so that the true vapor pressure of the product is

200 psig or less. Product is loaded out at atmospheric temperature on trucks that utilize pressurized, un-insulated tanks.

Refrigeration

The refrigeration system consists of the chiller mentioned above, and a set of electric motor driven compressors, refrigerant condensers and a refrigerant surge tank.  The refrigerant leaves the refrigerant surge tank as a liquid at a pressure of about 300 psig and is dumped through a valve to the cold side of the chiller where it vaporizes at low pressure (5 psig) to provide cooling of the gas.  The refrigerant vapor from the chiller is compressed through a set of electric motor driven compressors which compress the refrigerant vapor back up to 300 psig where it is cooled through a set of air cooled exchangers to about 20 degrees above atmospheric temperature.  As it cools, it condenses to the liquid phase and is then returned to the refrigerant surge tank.

Residue gas

The residue gas which leaves the gas to gas exchanger is routed to a final separator (outlet separator) at pressure that is about 20 psi below the inlet pressure and about 15 degrees below the inlet gas temperature.  No liquid is expected to be captured at the final separator-its purpose is to prevent an accidental carryover of liquids into the outlet gas piping.  From the outlet gas separator the residue gas is meter and returned to the gas pipeline.

Methanol injection

A small amount of methanol is injected into the inlet gas (about 5 BBLD, 20 BBLD max) to prevent freezing within the plant.  Some of this methanol is absorbed in the product along with traces of water condensed from the gas.  The remaining water condensed from the gas and the remaining unabsorbed methanol form a second liquid phase in the cold separator.  This second liquid phase is dumped from the cold separator directly to the atmospheric storage tank and is trucked off of the site.  

General Accident Release Prevention and Program Information

d equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service.  The PSSR team uses checklists to verify aspects of readiness and involves employee participation.

Devon Gas Services, L.P., has long-standing safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety.  Examples of these include, control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel, a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, a procedure for safe removal of hazardous substances before process piping or equipment is opened, a permit and procedure to control spark-producing activities (i.e., hot work) and a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space.  These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.

Devon Gas Services, L.P., has a comprehensive system to manage changes for covered processes.  This system monitors changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology, procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.  Changes are reviewed to ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage new hazards and verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change.  Affected chemical hazard information, processes, as well as procedures, are updated to incorporate these changes.  In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary training on the change.  

Devon Gas Services, L.P., investigates incidents that result in, or reasonably could result in, a fire/explosion, release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury.  The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to facility management for resolution.

t is regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) risk management program (RMP).  The Rothermel Conditioning Plant is not considered to be a PSM facility.  The Rothermel Conditioning Plant is classified as a normally unoccupied remote facility as per the definition found in 29 CFR 1910.119(b) and thus is not applicable to PSM requirements according to 29 CFR 1910.119(a)(2)(iii).  However, should this status change, the Rothermel Conditioning Plant must be re-evaluated for PSM applicability.  Devon's 'PSM Applicability' form can be seen in Appendix 1.    

Devon Gas Services, L.P., encourages employees to participate in safety and accident prevention.  Employees participate as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team.  Employees have access to facility accident prevention program.  

Devon Gas Services, L.P., keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes.  These documents will be located at the Groesbeck field office and address chemical properties and associated hazards.  

Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDSs).  The Rothermel Conditioning Plant also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment.  This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing maintenance activities.

Devon Gas Services, L.P., has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the process are identified and controlled.  Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.  

Devon Gas Services, L.P., primarily used the hazard and operability (HAZOP) analysis technique to perform this evaluation.  HAZOP analysis is recognized as

one of the most systematic and thorough hazard evaluation techniques.  The analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise.  This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and the team makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary.

The PHA team findings are forwarded to local and corporate management for resolution.  Implementation of mitigation options in response to PHA findings is based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA team.  This ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned the highest risk receive immediate attention.  All approved mitigation options in response to PHA team findings are tracked until they are completed.  The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.

Rothermel Conditioning Plant maintains written procedures that address various modes of operations.  These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  These procedures are periodically reviewed.  

Devon personnel are properly trained according to the facility operating procedures for process operations. The Rothermel Conditioning Plant has implemented a training program for all employees involved in operating a process.  New employees receive basic training in facility operations.  Refresher training is conducted on an as needed basis.  All of this training is documented for each operator.

The Rothermel Conditioning Plant uses contractors for maintenance and repair purposes.  Devon Gas Services, L.P., evaluates contractor safety programs and performance indicators.

ific Prevention Steps

The processes at the Rothermel Conditioning Plant have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation.  The following is a description of existing safety features applicable to the prevention of accidental releases of regulated substances in the facility.  

Universal Prevention Activities

The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to all RMP-covered processes at the Rothermel Conditioning Plant.  Collectively, these prevention program activities prevent or mitigate potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.

Specialized Safety Features

The Rothermel Conditioning Plant has safety features on many units to help (1) contain/control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release.  The following types of safety features are used in the covered process:

Release Detection

1.	Tanks are gauged
2.	Tanks/vessels are equipped with level and pressure sensors

Release Containment/Control

1.	Process relief valves venting vapors to the atmosphere to prevent vessels from rupturing
2.	Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual and automated)
3.	Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high temperature)
4.	Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system)

Release Mitigation

1.	Trained emergency response personnel
2.	Personal protective equipment (e.g., chemical protective clothing)
3.	SPCC Plan



Emergency Response Program Information

The Rothermel Conditioning Plant maintains a written emergency response program, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  The program consists of procedures for responding to the release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The procedures ad

dress all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post incident cleanup and decontamination requirements.  In addition, the facility has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment.  Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties.  The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to facility processes.  The emergency response program changes are administered through the Management of Change (MOC) process, which includes informing and/or training affected personnel in the changes. Periodic drills or tabletop exercises are conducted to test the response plan.

The overall emergency response program for the Rothermel Conditioning Plant is coordinated with the Limestone County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). Matt Groveton is the contact for the LEPC (254/729-5517).  This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives.  The Rothermel Conditioning Plant has around-the-clock communications capability.  Devon Gas Services, L.P., operators are automatically called in the event of a process upset.  The operator will then call the appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department).  This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  In addition to periodic LEPC meetings, the Devon Gas Services, L.P., conducts periodic emergency drills that involve emergency response organizations, and the Rothermel C

onditioning Plant provides annual refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated substances in the facility.  

Five - Year Accident History

The Rothermel Conditioning Plant has not yet been built as of March 2011.  According to Devon personnel, no accidents have occurred.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The Rothermel Conditioning Plant resolves all findings from PHAs, some of which result in modifications to the process. The most recent PHA was conducted on January 12 and 13, 2011. Minor changes to the P&IDs may be made after the date of this RMP.  Any changes affecting the quantities of any regulated substances will result in an update of this RMP. The following items were deemed major Hazards and are planned changes in response to the PHA:


Major Hazards Identified (Recommendations are being reviewed.)	Expected Completion Date
1.  Plant inlet line - Review adding a PI upstream of SE-1101 inlet ball valve.	Before plant start-up.
2.  SE*11042 Oil separator - Review installing a PSV and consult with manufacturer their philosophy regarding this.	
3.  AC 904/905/906/907/908/909/910/911 - Determine the MAWP, not specified on P&IDs and vendor was unsure.	
4.  Refrigerated compressors (All) - Request from manufacturer compressor curves.	
5.  Suction header - Review installing PALL, shutdown offending cell.	
6.  TK*1301 - Review that the tank can relieve at sufficient rate to prevent loss mechanical integrity.	
7.  TK*1301 - Review that the tank Enardo valve is dual action.	Before plant start-up.
8.  PCV*301 - Review that it can properly function if PRC*500 fails.	
9.  SE-1102 outlet separator - Review switch and float specific gravity operating parameters, scenario is liquid carry over from cold separator.
